Description: Digital photograph (colour); view of engraved, pecked rock art showing schematic figures of three humans, all upright and face on. Left to right: unidentified shape (human head and torso?); human figure with gap in infilled torso holding partially infilled pecked round object in each hand; stick figure style human figure with long vertical shape (spear?) in left hand and infilled round object (shield?) in other, with another line like second arm below. Karkur Talh, Sudan. Scanned
Curator's comments: Detail of 2013,2034.245. Karkur Tahl is the largest wadi (dry seasonal riverbed valley) in the sandstone eastern section of Jebel Uweinat, a granite and sandstone massif on the border of Egypt, Libya and Sudan. Karkur Talh is around 25 km long and lies mostly in Sudan, but partly within Egypt’s borders. There is an abundance of both painted and engraved rock art in shelters in the smaller side wadis. The engravings were first revealed to academia by Ahmed Hassanein in 1923 and a few photographs published in his report on the journey in National Geographic in 1924. A more comprehensive publication of rock art sites in Karkur Talh was made by Prince Kemal el Dine with Abbe Breuil in 1925 following his discovery of a painted cave in Karkur Talh. Further exploration and publications were made by numerous others including renowned explorer Ralph Bagnold’s expedition in 1931, with further exploration from László Almásy and Leo Frobenius in 1933. The largest professional exploration of the massif to date was made in 1968 by a team of Belgian scientists.
Acquisition name: Donated by: Trust for African Rock Art
